definition: The fundamental unit of quantum information, analogous to a classical bit but with the ability to exist in a superposition of states.
A quantum mechanical principle where a quantum system can exist in multiple states simultaneously until measured.
A quantum mechanical phenomenon where particles become correlated to predictably interact with each other regardless of distance.
A basic quantum circuit operating on a small number of qubits, analogous to classical logic gates.
The process of observing a quantum system, which causes it to collapse from a superposition of states into a definite state.
A sequence of quantum gates applied to a set of qubits to perform a quantum computation.
An algorithm that runs on a quantum computer, taking advantage of quantum mechanical phenomena like superposition and entanglement.
Techniques used to protect quantum information from errors due to decoherence and other quantum noise.
The loss of quantum coherence due to interaction with the environment, leading to the collapse of quantum states.
A process by which quantum information can be transmitted from one location to another, using a classical communication channel and quantum entanglement.
